texts: I had to wear the Star of David to play outside, and all this.

objects: everything our radios everything worthwhile art
texts: And when we moved there, gradually, other people moved in, because they tried kind of -- they evicted the Jews from homes and -- and they plunder, and they took everything away -- our radios and everything worthwhile, art.

Then you had to give up your bike.

objects: pork and smeared my lips on it
texts: I said, another time, I remember, you took pork, and you smeared my lips on it.

Easter time was bad, because on the eve of Easter, they either smashed your doors or they smashed your windows or they took away your horse and buggy.
Because you know -- not officially, but you know, some -- you know, either they would kick you or, or spit on you or hit you.
I know -- we had to -- in Lodz, we had to wear a yellow star.
So we were thrown out of public schools.
All these places would have signs on, Juden Jews and dogs forbidden.

And -- and I recall, in1936, when we got our first marking, where all -- where Jewish identification cards, carried by Jews -- and everybody had to carry identification cards, but the one for Jews had to be marked with the letter J, representing the German word Jude, Jew.

objects: the Star of David on all our clothes
texts: So in big pain, in the tremendous pain, my mother had to sew the Star on -- of David on all our clothes.

objects: the Jewish star with the word Jood
texts: And, of course, we -- at that time, when you were six years old or older, you had to wear the Jewish star with the word -- the yellow star -- you' ve seen it -- with the word' Jood.' That is Jew in -- in Dutch -- J- O- O- D.
But they closed all the bank accounts.
And it was -- we -- stones were thrown at us.

objects: the children to tie me up against a tree
texts: And as we came close back into town, the teacher encouraged the children to tie me up against a tree.

objects: already a yellow star on everything all the garments
texts: But the Jews had to wear already yellow -- a yellow star on everything, all the garments.

objects: a Star of David on our left side a Star of David on our backs

We had to walk in the gutter.
We couldn't go to school.
We couldn't go to work.
We couldn't walk on the sidewalk.
We'd walk in the gutter.
They would call you names, they would shove you off the sidewalks, they would -- those people that had the beards and peyots, you know, would pull them by the beards.
And there were always brawlings going on, and they would call you dirty Jew and stinky Jew.

objects: out with a yellow star to be affixed under the threat of death

And a Jew could not go on a train any more.
Now, they would also -- the Germans would also go, suddenly appear in town, and -- and whoever was Jewish -- and, of course, the Jews had to wear bands.
They smeared that with excreta and smashed all the windows and wrecked all the furniture.
They smeared that with excreta and smashed all the windows and wrecked all the furniture.
They smeared that with excreta and smashed all the windows and wrecked all the furniture.
Windows were broken in Jewish homes.
Jews could not drive a streetcar.
Jews couldn't have no cars, no nothing.
We knew that we were hated.

objects: a yellow star on our chests

objects: another announcement by the Germans new laws

objects: a time when we could not even go out to the streets

objects: store windows which had been smashed

objects: over to the authorities furs silver gold livestocks to the local authorities

objects: certain sections where they of the church

objects: the Star of David bands on the left arms

objects: on the streets near the gutters
texts: We had to walk on the streets near the gutters.

objects: it was a German we would have to step off the sidewalk and bow
texts: Then if we' ll walk on the street, and a German soldier or officer, or a German that -- like, somebody could tell it was a German -- walked by, we would have to step off the sidewalk and bow, even with the hat -- to take it off -- as a sign of respect to the master race.

objects: the star of David yellow the front the back of our dress clothes the outside our garments
texts: Well, the, the first one probably was, that we had to wear the star of David -- yellow -- the front and the back of our dress, clothes -- whatever -- on the outside our garments.

objects: them clean the streets with toothbrushes
texts: But they made them clean the streets with toothbrushes.

objects: on a band with a Magen David Star of David
texts: When I went back to Cracow, first of all I had to put on, since I was already a bar mitzvah age,13, I had to put on a band with a -- with a Magen David, Star of David, that indicated my faith or my Cain's spot, blot.
As such, I couldn't ride in any trolley.
I couldn't take any buses.
And in school, too, you know, they were singing songs against the Jews.
The next thing I know was that the -- all Jewish enterprises had to have a sign on -- on their window saying in three languages -- German, Dutch, and French -- Jewish Enterprise.

objects: the Christian prayers the Hail Mary the other prayers

And they had them work, sweep the streets, the sidewalks.
This is when we start -- had to wear -- that's when we had to wear the Star of David.
And you could not leave your home without it.

objects: a list of what you gave them

objects: yellow arm bands we would made
texts: And at the police station we had to wear yellow arm bands, and we would made -- we were given picks and shovels, and we were made to work labor on the highway department, different work, whether they needed it or not, just a form of harassing.
Other boy who played soccer on the same team than I did, for instance, pushed me off the sidewalk and said the Jews have to walk in the street.

objects: with the Gentiles in same river
texts: We couldn't swim with the Gentiles in same -- same river.

objects: tomatoes raw eggs in my face

objects: a white band with blue Magen David
texts: The Jews have to have a white band with blue Magen David, so everybody knows you're a Jew.

You could not go to the movies.

objects: a yellow Star of David yellow armband Star of David on our arms

objects: us to clean their homes barracks offices
texts: They forced us to clean their homes, barracks, offices, clean their cars, sweep the streets, shovel snow later.

They forced us to clean their homes, barracks, offices, clean their cars, sweep the streets, shovel snow later.

objects: very well dressed women to do very heavy work
texts: They enjoyed seeing very well dressed women to do very heavy work, and they forced very religious Jews to pray and sing and dance in the streets while they were cutting their beards and their earlocks.

objects: very religious Jews to pray and sing and dance in the streets while they were cutting their beards and their earlocks

They didn't want Jews to contaminate their books.

objects: to a barber shop to have my hair cut
texts: I remember, as a child I couldn't go to a barber shop to have my hair cut.

objects: off the pavement for the same reason

objects: theirself Israel as a second name

objects: out of all the government jobs out of radio the theater the movie industry

objects: in all the bank accounts all the jewelry very quick

objects: all the silver that your gold money

objects: a place all the silver all the candelabras the menorahs the silver cups every one my father left

objects: me dirty a dirty Jewish child

texts: All Jewish children had to get out of the ordinary schools in spring1938, I think.
And I remember we, as Jews, we couldn't get into the streetcars.

objects: a Jew with a beard and pull his beard and make fun of him
texts: Oh, they would catch a Jew with a beard and pull his beard and make fun of him.
Parks were off limit.
My father -- Jews were thrown out of jobs.
Anybody had -- the teachers and professors were dismissed from universities.
That was a law that a Jew couldn't use any train, couldn't use any streetcars.
That was a law that a Jew couldn't use any train, couldn't use any streetcars.

objects: a law that every Jew had to wear the Star of David
texts: It was a law that every Jew had to -- had to wear the Star of David.

objects: only certain streets not the main streets on a certain boardwalk
texts: That was a law that the Jews could go only certain streets -- not the main streets, and not on -- on every boardwalk -- but a certain boardwalk -- what was prescribed for Jews only, and so forth.

objects: out to the street to sweep the streets you know with a little broom
texts: I just didn't appear, and I was caught, and I was brought out to the street to sweep the streets, you know, with a little broom and pick up the garbage, you know, with my hands.

objects: that Jewish children could not sit next to Gentile children
texts: Yes, I went to a Jewish school, because after the Crystal Night, we were told -- all schools were told that Jewish children could not sit next to Gentile children.
And I had to wear the Star of David.

objects: the schools completely for the Jews
texts: The gymnasium came much later, and it was only one year before they closed the schools completely for the Jews.
And we had to give all the jewelry away, and fur coats.
He screamed at me, you dirty Jew.
We had to give up all our pets in'38.
that all Jewish families have to collect their silverware and deliver it to the Jewish committee at their headquarters.
And they had -- they took some religious Jews what they had the beard, and they unrolled the Torah and the men had to step on the Torah.

objects: some gasoline and light the Torahs
texts: And then they had to take some gasoline and light the, the, the Torahs and that made a fire.
